Context.Summary: The Nathu La and Cho La clashes were a series of military engagements between India and China in September and October 1967. These skirmishes occurred at Nathu La and Cho La, located on the border between China and the Kingdom of Sikkim, then a protectorate of India. The confrontations stemmed from the broader Sino-Indian border dispute and were among the most significant military conflicts between the two countries following the 1962 Sino-Indian War. The clashes at Nathu La and Cho La are notable for their intensity and the use of artillery and infantry. The Indian Army successfully repelled the Chinese offensive, resulting in a strategic victory for India. These clashes marked a turning point in the Sino-Indian relations, leading to a tactical and psychological advantage for India in the ongoing border tensions.

Nathu_La_and_Cho_La_Clashes.Location: Nathu La and Cho La, on the border between China and the Kingdom of Sikkim

India: Gen. P. P. Kumaramangalam (Chief of the Army Staff)
China: Maj. Gen. Wang Chenghan (Deputy commander of the Tibet Military District)
